title: Andy Dalton says it's 'unfortunate' Bengals didn't give him more time to pursue trade
text:
CLOSE What I'm Hearing: Bengals are hoping that their rookie QB will help end their losing streak. USA TODAY

The changing of the guard at the quarterback position officially happened on a rainy Wednesday morning in Cincinnati.

A day after learning he wouldn't be the starter going forward, Andy Dalton spoke to the media for the first time as a backup.

“Weird, different, not what I was expecting. It's not how you thought the birthday was going to go. It's an unfortunate situation,” Dalton said. “I don't agree with it. Zac's making the decisions so I'm going to do my part. I'm here, and so I'm going to try and help out Ryan the best I can.”

Dalton revealed that Taylor told him that his decision was in part because the team wants to evaluate Finley before the 2020 NFL Draft.

“He said he has to think about the future with the draft and we have to see what we have in Ryan. That's what it came down to,” Dalton said. “It's been voiced to me I wasn't the reason for the way the season has gone. I felt like I played well and have done some things to keep this team together in this stretch, but he just feels like he has to figure out what they have in Ryan.”

MORE: Browns QB Baker Mayfield ends news conference after contentious exchange with reporter

The fact that Dalton divulged that Taylor was thinking about the future when possessing and ultimately reaching a QB conclusion is an indication that the Bengals are embracing a rebuild. A rebuild that Dalton realistically won’t be a part of.

Dalton, understandably frustrated, spoke with the realism that his days as Cincinnati’s starting quarterback could be numbered. He admitted that he wished Taylor informed him of the move well before Tuesday’s 4 p.m. trade deadline, so he and his agent could explore the NFL market for QB-needy teams.

“I think that's an unfortunate thing. It happened three hours before the trade deadline,” Dalton said. “I wish if he was thinking about it at least let me try to see if I could end up somewhere else or at least see if there's interest in possibly getting traded. At that point, the way it was handled there wasn't enough time to even have that happen.”

Now that the trade deadline has passed, Dalton has to shift gears, acquiesce to the backup job and support Finley. It’s something that he’s willing to do. He and Finley have already had multiple discussions since the quarterback shuffle.

“Ryan was one of the first people I reached out to just to let to him know this has nothing to do with Ryan. Ryan and I have been close ever since he's been here. We've built up a really good friendship. I don't want Ryan to think I have any ill will toward him,” Dalton said. “He didn't do anything wrong. All he did was be here and show up and do things the right way and they want to give him an opportunity. I'm going to help him out.”

Ryan Finley took first-team reps with the Bengals offense Wednesday and threw his first pass to the best player on the roster.

“It was fun,” Finley said of his first practice as a starter. “I threw my first pass to A.J. Green, so that was exciting. The weather is what it is, but it was fun to get out there.”

The 0-8 Bengals practiced on Wednesday before taking much-needed break from football. Many of the players plan to go back home and spend time with family. Finley is going to treat the bye week as extra time to prepare for his Week 10 rookie debut at Paul Brown Stadium versus the Baltimore Ravens.

“Going into a bye week, that’s huge for me. Just kind of a chance to get a fresh start. Zac is kind of preaching a new season, so that’s kind of the mindset. It’s kind of a fresh start. Everybody gets away for a couple days and come back and ready to work,” Finley said Wednesday. “It gives me a chance to watch more film and get with Zac (Taylor), Alex (Van Pelt), Brian (Callahan) and Andy (Dalton) and just get ready to go.”

The Bengals aren’t easing in the North Carolina State product by any means. His first test is against the AFC North-leading Ravens. Still, the rookie signal caller is looking forward to trotting out there with his teammates for the Week 10 tilt and is excited for the chance to start.

“Yeah, it’ll be fun. It’s part of the game, so it’s something that I just got to get thrown in there and I’ll figure it out. I got a lot of guys around me that know what they are doing. I feel confident about that,” Finley said.

Barring an injury, Dalton’s time as the Bengals’ starter appears to be over. He’s started 128 games over the course of nine seasons for the franchise. He only trails Ken Anderson for the most passing yards in team history and the two are deadlocked at No.1 for most passing touchdowns with 197.

Will Dalton throw another touchdown pass with the Bengals? He doesn’t know. To his credit, he’s committed to the task at hand, which is being a team player as a backup quarterback.

“Right now, I'm just focused on this year,” Dalton said. “Obviously there is a lot to come in the next eight weeks and beyond after this year.”

What he does know is he still wants to be a starting quarterback in the NFL. The odds of him reclaiming his starting spot in the Queen City aren’t in his favor. Cincinnati and Dalton, who has one more year remaining on his contract, appear to be headed for a divorce after a nine-year relationship.

“I want to have an opportunity to play, I want to have an opportunity to be somewhere where I'm wanted,” Dalton said. “If that's here great, if that's not then we'll see.”

The writing is on the wall. Taylor and the Bengals are ready to move in a different direction under center.

description: Andy Dalton was benched on his birthday, and the Bengals QB wishes he had been granted a bigger window to look into a possible trade
